item.title: Java crashing
item.dc:creator: @WoW_sucks Dave
item.description:
@WoW_sucks wrote:

Grr this is getting annoying =[

Please just fix it and re-post, if you wouldn’t mind =/

[code]import javax.swing.;
import java.io.;
import java.awt.;
import java.awt.event.;

public class GUI extends JComponent implements KeyListener {

int ourX;
int ourY;
public static boolean keyPressed = false;

public String[] image = { "bg", "odish" };

public Graphics g = img.getGraphics();   
public GUI() {addKeyListener(this); }
	
public void paint(Graphics g) {
		
	g.drawImage(sprite(1), 0, 0, null);
	g.drawImage(sprite(2), ourX, ourY, null);			
}
 
 public Image sprite(int spriteToPaint) {
	Image img = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getImage("./pics/" + image[spriteToPaint - 1] + ".png");
	return img;
}
	
public void keyPressed(KeyEvent e) {
	GUI.keyPressed = true;
		switch (e.getKeyCode())
		{
			case 37:  //left
			
				break;
			case 38:  //up
				ourY = ourY + 5;
				break;
			case 39: //right
			
				break;
			case 40: //down
			
				break;
				
			default:
				break;
	}
	GUI.update(g);		
			
}
	
public void keyReleased(KeyEvent e) {}
public void keyTyped(KeyEvent e) {}

}
[/code]

Errors: cannot find symbol variable img
: non-static method update(java.awt.Graphics) cannot be referenced from a static context

Sorry that i’m shit at java =/

Read full topic

item.title: Java crashing
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

In GUI declare this above 'public GUI() {}"

public Graphics g = img.getGraphics();

also your keylistener stuff should all be in your startIt file.

Read full topic

item.title: Java crashing
item.dc:creator: @WoW_sucks Dave
item.description:
@WoW_sucks wrote:

Ok, last one before i’m going to bed:

It’s having an error with this: GUI.update(g);

I have public Graphics g at the top, as a global and it gives this error: non-static method update(java.awt.Graphics) cannot be referenced from a static context

I tried changing it to static but no look =/

Read full topic

item.title: Java crashing
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

  1. in the class that draws the picture, which in your case would be GUI, declare keyPressed as false and replace SpriteHandler with GUI

  2. replace CLASS with the class that draws, which again is GUI

  3. yuppurz

Read full topic

item.title: Java crashing
item.dc:creator: @WoW_sucks Dave
item.description:
@WoW_sucks wrote:

Ok, i get all of that except a few small bits:

SpriteHandler.keyPressed = true; - Don’t know what that is/does and it also gives me this error: cannot find symbol variable SpriteHandler

CLASS.update(g); - Don’t know what that is/does and it also gives me this error: cannot find symbol variable CLASS

And is this bit: getGraphics().drawImage((Image)img, 0, 0, null); supposed to represent my paint method? :S

Sorry about all the questions.

Read full topic

item.title: Java crashing
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

implements KeyListener 
addKeyListener(this);  
  public void keyPressed(KeyEvent e)
	{
		SpriteHandler.keyPressed = true;
		switch (e.getKeyCode())
		{
			
			
			case 37:  //left
							
				//what to do
				
				break;
			case 38:  //up
				
							
				
				break;

			case 39: //right
				
					
				
				break;
			case 40: //down
				
				
				break;
			default:
				

				break;
		}
		
		CLASS.update(g);
		getGraphics().drawImage((Image)img, 0, 0, null);

		
		
	}

Switch lets it switch through different keycodes repeatedly, and each key has a key code, 37-40 are up down left and right.

You will also need to add a method to the CLASS that paints the playerimage

Read full topic

I was trying something like this:

@Unhandled wrote:

Thread.sleep() and GUIs should never go together.

item.title: Java crashing
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

I got it working for you

import javax.swing.*;
import java.io.*;
import java.awt.*;
 
 
public class startIt extends JFrame {

	public static void main(String[] args)
	{
	makeFrame();
	}
 	

	public static void makeFrame() {
			
		
		JFrame frame = new JFrame();	
					
		frame.setContentPane(new GUI());	
		frame.setSize(140, 140);
		frame.setResizable(false);
		frame.setVisible(true);
		try
   			{
     			Thread.sleep(200); 
    			}
		catch(InterruptedException e) {}
		frame.setSize(200,200);
		
	}
}

the sleep at the beginning is like a quick repaint, it just makes it bigger making it repaint. lul

gui

import javax.swing.*;
import java.io.*;
import java.awt.*;
 
 
public class GUI extends JComponent {
	
	public static JPanel main = new JPanel();
	public String[] image = { "bg", "odish" };

	public GUI() {}
	
	public void paint(Graphics g) {

		g.drawImage(sprite(1), 0, 0, null);
			
	}
	
	
 
	 public Image sprite(int spriteToPaint)
	{
		
		Image img = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getImage("./pics/" + image[spriteToPaint - 1] + ".png");
		return img;
	}
 
}

Oops i was a bit late on this one. Im having the same problem with having to minimize it etc, so i just created an auto minimize then maximize in 200 milisecs

Read full topic

[code=java]import javax.swing.;
import java.io.;
import java.awt.*;

public class GUI extends JPanel {

private Image pic = null;
private Image bg = null;

@Override
public void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
	
	try {  
		if (bg == null)
			bg = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getImage("bg.png");
		g.drawImage(bg, 0, 0, null);
	} catch (Exception e) {
		e.printStackTrace();
	}
	
	
	try {  
		if (pic == null)
			pic = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getImage("odish.png");
		g.drawImage(pic, 20, 20, null);
	} catch (Exception e) {
		e.printStackTrace();
	}
}

public GUI() {		
	
	JFrame frame = new JFrame("Display Image");	
				
	frame.setContentPane(new GUI());
	//frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
	frame.setSize(200, 200);
	frame.setResizable(false);
	frame.setVisible(true);
	
}

}
[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Java crashing
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

dont call paint(getGraphics());

use repaint() instead

also, dont override paint() for swing components, which includes JFrame
override paintComponent() instead

also, dont draw on the JFrame, but draw on your own JPanel, and put it on the JFrame with setContentPane()
cause you see, you’re drawing on the entire JFrame, but swing supports more then that, with your method, you cant add a menu bar, or other stuff,
so use setContentPane()

JFrame has a JRootPane which contains its Content Pane, its JMenuBar, and its JLayeredPane,
when you override paint() you are removing all that functionality

kind of like this

public class MyImagePanel extends JPanel {

    @Override
    public void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
        //draw stuff
    }
}

/////
/////

JFrame frame = new JFrame("Display Image");
//other JFrame stuff, ie. setDefaultCloseOperation()
frame.setContentPane(new MyImagePanel());
frame.setVisible(); //should always be the last thing

Read full topic

item.title: Java crashing
item.dc:creator: @WoW_sucks Dave
item.description:
@WoW_sucks wrote:

c|p helped me with this on the IRC, my new problem is when i try to load an image for the background, i have to minimize the application to see the changes in effect.

This is my new code:

[code=Java]import javax.swing.;
import java.io.;
import java.awt.*;

public class GUI extends JFrame {

private Image pic = null;
private Image bg = null;

public GUI() {		
	super("Display Image");
	this.setDefaultCloseOperation(EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
	this.setSize(200, 200);
	this.setResizable(false);
	this.setVisible(true);
	
	try {
	Thread.sleep(20);
	paint(getGraphics());
	} catch (InterruptedException e) {
	}
}

public void paint(Graphics g) {
	
	try {  
		if (bg == null)
			bg = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getImage("bg.png");
		g.drawImage(bg, 0, 0, null);
	} catch (Exception e) {
		e.printStackTrace();
	}
	
	
	try {  
		if (pic == null)
			pic = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getImage("odish.png");
		g.drawImage(pic, 20, 20, null);
	} catch (Exception e) {
		e.printStackTrace();
	}
}

}
[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Java crashing
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

this.setDefaultCloseOperation(EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
this.setSize(200, 200);
this.setResizable(false);
this.setVisible(true);

when you set it visible it runs paint(Graphics), i dont think it runs it when setSize is called, try setting it visible after seting the size and all other settings.

Read full topic

item.title: Java crashing
item.dc:creator: @WoW_sucks Dave
item.description:
@WoW_sucks wrote:

When i try and run this java app my java just crashes and i don’t have any idea why.

As you can see from the image, the background oh the application is the same as the top corner from where the app started (I dragged it to show people).

I’m pretty sure that’s “Crashed”.

I’d appreciate any help. Thanks!

[code=java]import javax.swing.;
import java.io.;
import java.awt.*;

public class GUI extends JFrame {

public GUI() {
	
	super("Display Image");
	JPanel P = (JPanel)this.getContentPane();
	P.setLayout(null);

	this.setVisible(true);
	this.setDefaultCloseOperation(EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
	this.setSize(200, 200);
	this.setResizable(false);
}
		
public void paint(Graphics g) {
	try {  
	Image img = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getImage("odish.png");
	g.drawImage(img, 20, 20, null);
	} catch(Exception e) { 
		e.printStackTrace(); }
}

}[/code]

Read full topic
